data.title: Shannon RFC on LinkedIn: #enjoy #7s #rugby
data.meta_description: Shannon RFC are well represented at The Emirates Dubai 7s with Shannon RFC & Munster Referee John A.,  Olympian Greg O’Shea and Eugene Deegan  #enjoy  #7s…
data.text:
Its always a pleasure and a privilege to be able to put these articles together. Many thanks, as always, to all at iSportConnect for the opportunity. It is also a very stimulating exercise that stretches the brain and forces one to confront some uncomfortable truths. I hope readers find the attached 5 minute read thought-provoking and that it stimulates some debate and conversation. My over-riding concern is that technology has been introduced onto the field of play with a blind faith that "all tech is good tech" and that it will undoubtedly improve things (as it has off the field for the sports industry). However, if it is not adding to spectator experience and enjoyment, if it undermines the decisions of officials, if it creates confusion, is not replicable throughout the sport, does not add to player safety and clarity, and is unhelpful to broadcasters then it is likely to meet with widespread antipathy. After another weekend of VAR controversy (and a near 2-hour long game of football at the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium last night) one has to consider whether doubling-down on this technology is really the best move by the likes of The Premier League and World Rugby. Yes, it creates column-inches and social media comment but ultimately the constant angst around technological review of every action will chip away at the view of the "product" and erode it from the bottom-up. This will be tough to detect until it is potentially too late for "top down" organisations like most sports governing bodies. Andy Sutherden Roger Mitchell Andrew Brember Pierre Justo Andrew Milnes Spencer Nolan Lynsey Pennie-Douglas Michael Jones Nicole Allison (She/Her) Tim Goodman Tracy Schoenadel Sandra Greer Sandy Case Adam Fraser

The Power of Team Spirit: Lessons from the Stormers In the world of sports, the story of the Stormers stands as a testament to the incredible power of team spirit. Despite facing challenges and resource constraints, this remarkable team has shown us what true resilience and unity can accomplish. In project management, just like in rugby, the spirit of the team is often the cornerstone of success. The Stormers' journey reminds us that when a team is united by a shared vision and a collective determination, even the most daunting obstacles can be overcome. It's not always about having the most resources, but how effectively a team can leverage its strengths and work cohesively towards a common goal. This principle is especially relevant in the field of civil engineering and construction projects, where complexities and uncertainties are a norm. Here, the spirit of a team doesn't just contribute to overcoming challenges; it becomes the driving force that pushes the boundaries of what we can achieve. Let's take inspiration from the Stormers and strive to foster a team spirit that thrives on collaboration, resilience, and shared purpose. As we engrain this spirit into our teams, we unlock the potential to achieve remarkable feats, regardless of the resources at hand. Project Management Institute PMI South Africa Chapter #TeamSpirit #ProjectManagement #Resilience #Collaboration #Leadership
